description: Inherited from Middle English pykeaxe, pecaxe, pyke exe (“pickaxe”), an alteration (due to folk etymology association with pick and axe) of Middle English pikeyse, pikeys, pykois, from Anglo-Norman *pikeis, Old French picois, pecois, from Latin picōsa (“pickaxe”), from picca, ultimately from Proto-West Germanic *pīk (“sharp point, pike”). Doublet of pique and pike.

entries.meaning: A heavy iron tool with a wooden handle; one end of the head is pointed, the other has a chisel edge.

verbs.description: pickaxe (third-person singular simple present pickaxes, present participle pickaxing, simple past and past participle pickaxed)
